author: axic3354
content:
I was trying to hold myself back from commenting here, but I do not appreciate calling it out as "violating rules". I have explained my position there in several comments, for example in https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/3540#issuecomment-841198049

Can you please explain what rules you are referring to?

author: axic3354
content: And I would prefer to have the answer on github so it is searchable and can be referenced later on for clarity. Unfortunately discord is ephemeral and in my opinion not good for discussions relating to EIP decisions.

author: sky.cactus
content: Unwritten (I think) rules that we have discussed in editor meetings that external links shouldn't be allowed/used.

author: axic3354
content: I think it is really bad practice enforcing unwritten rules and not letting people know what those are. Ideally they would be written rules, so nobody is confused.

author: sky.cactus
content: As you know, EIP editors are quite understaffed, so it is not uncommon for things to be discussed and decisions made without them making it into written form.

author: axic3354
content: (When I was more active I do not believe we enforced many unwritten rules, to be fair.)

author: sky.cactus
content: Usually we just start telling people the new thing during review, which works well in most cases because the majority of authors don't actually read the written instructions anyway.

author: sky.cactus
content: I think there are only 4-5 authors who are actually familiar with the written rules (mostly past EIP editors), which is usually when contention arises.

author: sky.cactus
content: FWIW, I think your distaste for this process is reasonable, and I think everyone wishes we had the manpower to do better.

author: axic3354
content:
I really think enforcing strict rules for drafts is entirely pointless, given once it is merged as a draft, authors can do whatever they want. Nobody will be policing that. The next time it is policed when a status change is requested.

Draft really was supposed to be enforcing that it fulfils the structure requirements, i.e. the header and existence of sections, but not the content. The content is reviewed during Review/Last Call/Final.

author: sky.cactus
content: The reason the no external link rule (and in fact most of the new rules) exist is because we don't have the manpower to do nuanced reviews, and strict rules are far easier to enforce than fuzzy rules.  "No external links" vs "some external links".

author: axic3354
content: Editors are not supposed to do content reviews to this extent. It is the role of reviewers. Editors supposed to fulfil a role of structural checks, not content checks.

author: axic3354
content: I think given you are active on ACD you are chiming as a Reviewer too, but that is a distinct role from Editor.

author: axic3354
content: And mixing the two together is one source of contention.

author: axic3354
content:
At least the above was original set up from the get go and was the way things went up until end of last year ðŸ™‚

Potentially this was revised but nobody ever documented the changes in these roles.

author: sky.cactus
content: This is the heart of the schism at the moment.  Some believe that EIPs should be written as standards from start to finish and people should go elsewhere if they want a link repository.  Others think that EIPs should be a place to discuss and collect data and links.  Some think draft is one and final is the other, while others think all phases should be one or the other.

author: axic3354
content:
I really disagreed with this approach when it was introduced around 2016 (i.e. merge draft as early as possible so it has a fixed URL), but it has been the process ever since then. And at this point maybe I am just used to it or it has grown on me.

I think changing this process through "editor reviews" is not a good idea. It should be changed via revising EIP-1.

author: sky.cactus
content: I think everyone agrees that we **should** update EIP-1 when decisions are made.

author: sky.cactus
content: The problem is that it ends up getting dropped/forgotten because everyone involved is too busy.
